name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on five motions for resolutions on the situation of LGBTI people in Uganda (2019/2879(RSP)). Before the start of the debate, I would like to inform you that, in order to speak with the catch-the-eye procedure or to ask a question with a blue card, you can use both the usual registration method and the new electronic registration system. For this reason, I would ask you to always bring the voting card with you. If you wish to register for the catch-the-eye process, you can start now without waiting for the end of the discussion.

name: Ellie CHOWNS
text: author. – Mr President, I am very pleased that we have such strong cross-party support for this debate on this resolution in this Parliament today. I think this is testament to how far attitudes have moved in my own lifetime, indeed.  We stand here today in solidarity with those brave members of sexual minorities in Uganda and elsewhere who face not just public prejudice, but also the full force of the State aimed at repressing their very nature. The bravery of those activists is truly admirable. They stand up in the most hostile of circumstances to say ‘We are who we are. We are equal in dignity and rights and we should be free’.  The situation in Uganda is indeed very worrying. The killing of Brian Wasswa earlier this month was a horrific act and the perpetrator must be brought to justice. The deliberate stoking of anti-gay hatred by government ministers must be absolutely and strongly condemned. With this resolution we are calling on the Ugandan Government to fully respect the rights of LGBTQIA people, not just to stop the whole hate-filled rhetoric but to ensure that Ugandan law does not discriminate against anyone on the grounds of sexual orientation or gender identity. Today we say to everyone fighting for those rights in Uganda, and worldwide: we in Europe stand with you.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: Author. – Mr President, I too would like to thank colleagues from the different parliamentary groups for having a resolution with so much information and, above all, with so much agreement on an issue that is so essential. However, we have to take into account that discrimination based on sexual orientation is not an exclusive to Uganda. Unfortunately, it is a permanent setback that we have seen in various parts of the world, including also in countries of the European Union.  In making this resolution, we draw attention to the need to have a path that places the equality of all people in all relations, whether within the european union, but also with countries such as Uganda.  In future agreements, the European Union must take into account what is included in the Cotonou Agreement and ensure that there is no discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation, that this reference is included.  We cannot witness, as we have seen in recent months, the death, the cruel murder of activists or a young transgender woman, as we have seen in Uganda. And that is why this resolution is important and that is why we have to move from words to deeds and ensure that discrimination based on sexual orientation is not a reality that we can assume neither here nor anywhere in the world.

name: Karin KARLSBRO
text: author. – (start of speech off mike) Mr President […] should not be a crime. Yet this is the case in more than 70 countries around the world. We felt repulsed last week when members of the Ugandan Government expressed support for a proposal to introduce a punishment that should not exist for an act that is not criminal – capital punishment for homosexual activities. Whether or not this proposal is adopted, homosexuality is already a crime in Uganda and LGBT people are subject to cruel violence and discrimination. The government not only allows this to happen; they fuel it. It’s our duty to stand up for human rights and the EU should take a leading role in abolishing capital punishment everywhere. I want to entire LGBT community of Uganda to know that the European Parliament stands with them, because love can never be a crime.  (applause)

name: Julie WARD
text: author. – Mr President, in light of the alarming rise in attacks against LGBTI people in Uganda, the resolution we have before us today is of great importance. Three gay men and one transgender woman have been murdered in Uganda this year, the latest being the LGBTI activist, Brian Wasswa, who was attacked in his home on 4 October. The general deterioration of human rights of LGBTI persons in Uganda is very worrying, including increasing violations of their social rights, freedom of expression and gender equality rights. This resolution calls on our important cooperation with Uganda. We have got to support all efforts aimed at removing punitive laws, policies, practices, stigma and discrimination that undermine human rights. We call on the EU to enhance the defence and promotion of human rights in Uganda, notably through targeted support to NGOs and full implementation of the EU guidelines on human rights defenders. We also call for all of us to form the strongest opposition to all forms of discrimination based on sexual orientation. Old colonial laws have no place in the 21st century world.

name: Tomas TOBÉ
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking all colleagues who have worked on this resolution. It is basically about standing up for LGBTQ rights globally, that is, human rights. The EU should be a driving force for everyone, regardless of sexual orientation, to have freedom and security. Unfortunately, we know that the situation in very many countries is far from this.  The situation of LGBTQ people in Uganda is already very serious. The latest proposal that has now been discussed in the debate on the introduction of the death penalty for homosexual acts is, of course, completely unacceptable. I certainly welcome the fact that we have received statements from the government saying that some new legislative initiatives are not under way. That's something we mean obliges. But nor does it change the situation that we are already seeing in Uganda, today with vicious rhetoric and homophobia. We even see a situation where homosexuals are murdered.  We believe that this must have greater consequences from the international community. Receiving EU development funds also comes with demands for human rights. As far as Europe is to be based, we will now be ready to engage in dialogue with the government, but also with civil society. For the absolute most important thing to achieve now, it is that we on the ground improve the situation of LGBTQ people. I would therefore urge all colleagues in the European Parliament to vote in favour of this resolution. It is fundamentally a question of standing up for human rights, but also of the rule of law.

name: Maria WALSH
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, it is unacceptable that sexual orientation continues to be used as a justification for serious human rights violations around the world. LGBTI rights are human rights.  What we are witnessing in Uganda and Indonesia falls within the competency of our European Union. Discrimination against LGBTI persons undermines the most basic human rights principles enshrined by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. This Parliament has an obligation to react to human rights violations and we also have an obligation to ensure other institutions also act.  It is important, it is highly important, that we ask our new Commission and our Council, in accordance with the LGBTI guidelines, to include our community members in Uganda and Indonesia in their dialogues with the governments of these countries. We must have a dialogue to change discrimination laws, combat homophobia and prejudice against LGBITQ community members and protect our communities from their violence.  We now have to lead. As an LGBTIQ community member myself, if the killing of three gay men and one transgender woman happened in Ireland? We should therefore protect our citizens in Uganda.

name: Alex AGIUS SALIBA
text: f'isem il-grupp S&D. – Sur President, sfortunatament id-drittijiet umani ta' persuni LGBTI għadhom jinkisru ta' kuljum madwar id-dinja kollha, u l-Uganda mhux e大大ezzjoni; fejn il-membri ta' komunità LGBTI għadhom qed jiġu soġġetti għal attakki brutali. Persuni LGBTI għandhom id-dritt tal- protezzjoni ugwali u għall-istess drittijiet bħal kulħadd.  Fil-qalba tal-vjolenza fil-konfront tal-komunità LGBTI hemm il-preġudizzju u l-mibegħda. Għandna bżonn nibdlu l-mentalità jekk irridu li jirnexxielna nevitaw dawn ir-reati. Irridu nkunu kuraġużi biżżejjed biex nindirizzaw dawn il-fatturi mal-faxex kollha tas-sojet大à. Għaldaqstant huwa essenzjali li niddefendu u nipproteġu din il-komunità madwar id-dinja minn hawk tip ta' vjolenza u diskriminazzjoni.  Għandna bżonn niżguraw li n-nies kollha, irrispettivament mill-orjentazzjoni sesswali tagħhom u mill-identità tal-ġeneru jkollhom id-dritt li jkunu ugwali f'għajnejn il-liġi mingħajr l-ebda e大ezzjoni.  U Malta hija eżempju tajjeb ħafna għall-Ewropa. Matul dawn l-aħħar sitt snin ġew introdotti għadd ta' liġijiet progressivi - minn unjoni ħiħvili għal drittijiet ta' adozzjoni ugwali għal koppji tal-istess sess. Bdejna mill-qiegħ u issa Malta tinsab l-ewwel fil-a-klassifika tal-ILGA-Europe f'dak li għandu x'jaqsam ma' dawn id-drittijiet.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, we still remember the debates in 2014 when a law was introduced in Uganda to punish homosexuality with the death penalty and it was precisely the pressure of the international community that caused this law to withdraw. However, in Uganda, homosexuality remains within the Penal Code and is punishable by harsh penalties. The day-to-day life of LGTBI people is very hard because they do not have access to basic services such as education or healthcare, and we have alarmedly witnessed the announcement of a possible return to tighten that law with harsher penalties as again the death penalty.  We are glad that this is not the case, but this Resolution gives a very clear message: we cannot allow a single step back in the advancement, in freedom, in the rights of the LGTBI community. In Uganda we have to take steps forward, homosexuality must be decriminalized because it is not a crime and sexual orientation is a human right. And the European Union has to use political dialogue to defend the rights of these people.

name: Rasmus ANDRESEN
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the In early October, 28-year-old Brian Wasswa was brutally murdered in Uganda because he was gay. He was stabbed ten times in the head with sharp knives. The murder of Brian Wasswa came at a time when the Ugandan government announced the introducing the death penalty for homosexuals. For years, homosexuals in Uganda have had to fear for their lives. Newspapers publish images and addresses of LGBTI people, and a brutal smear campaign is taking place. The anti-LGBTI smear campaign must end. The debate on the introduction of the death penalty alone is seriously damaging, and we should strongly condemn it. All people should have the right to love and to live in freedom. The European Union is giving EUR 578 million in development aid to Uganda, and that is another reason why we have a responsibility. Homosexuality is criminalised in 70 countries worldwide and the death penalty in nine. Let us do everything we can together to put an end to this. Let all LGBTI people around the world be given freedom!

name: Assita KANKO
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, two African countries criminalise same—sex relations. Four of them punish homosexuality with death. This is a heartbreaking and awful statistic. I have spent my whole life trying to help others fight intolerance and discrimination. When I was a kid I couldn’t imagine what my life would be if I had not been heterosexual. A lot of conversations I heard referred to homosexuals as criminals or people who are not clean. It’s really awful to know that today this is still the case. It has also been my experience that to really achieve meaningful and lasting change in attitudes and beliefs, you not only have to condemn and be bold or sound sad, but also promote education programmes and community dialogue for concrete and sustainable results. We need to help increase trust between local people and the NGOs who carry out the brave and important work of protecting the LGBTI community in these countries. Europe needs to work together with communities, police forces and the political system of these countries to bring an end to this deplorable situation. We must use every opportunity we have in our dialogue with these countries to promote tolerance, education and understanding, because everyone has a right to be free and everyone has a right to live and love without fear.

name: Eugenia RODRÍGUEZ PALOP
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, in Uganda, homosexual relations are punishable by life imprisonment because they contravene natural order, a fanciful appeal used since the Middle Ages that has brought homosexual people to death in many parts of the world. Murdering them is what the new U.S. Minister of Ethics and Integrity wants to do now, although already, in 2014, the Constitutional Court declared this same attempt null and void.  Here is the nefarious influence of the churches and their particular crusade against evil, acting from the very bowels of the State; and it's not about giving lessons, because religious lobbies are sitting in this Parliament and in many state parliaments.  And yesterday we had a debate in this chamber on an anti-discrimination directive which has been blocked in the Council for ten years. Here is also seated an extreme right homophobic and tansfuga.  Nor is it a question of withholding financial aid to Uganda, further punishing a vulnerable population, as has been done on other occasions. We need to censor these kinds of initiatives without mitigation, but to be credible, we must adequately protect the LGTBI collective and ensure that all states offer asylum and refuge to those persecuted for their sexual orientation and gender identity. Shall we do it? Here's what we have to ask ourselves when we talk about Uganda.

name: David BULL
text: – Mr President, discrimination against anyone on the grounds of their sexuality is absolutely abhorrent. There are around half a million LGBTI people in Uganda and yet homosexuality is still illegal. Same—sex marriage is constitutionally banned and LGBTI people are unable to express themselves freely. They are oppressed. They are socially imprisoned and often violently attacked. But fortunately, attitudes in Uganda are shifting rapidly. In 2007, a poll showed that 96% believed that same—sex relationships should be outlawed, but by 2017 an ILGA poll found that number had dramatically dropped to just 54% – so social and cultural change is happening. But the bigger question is, why is the EU meddling yet again in the affairs of a democratically—elected country? This talking shop will not help people in Uganda. Hollow words in this Chamber may make us feel self—righteous, but they have no impact at all on the persecuted LGBTI people in Uganda. Uganda itself must reform and it must allow LGBTI people to live and love in peace.

name: Mónica Silvana GONZÁLEZ
text: – Mr President, Africa needs us, Uganda needs us, but development cooperation and humanitarian aid must be accompanied by a clear and concrete demand for respect for the dignity of all people — and all people are also LGTBI people.  Eradicating poverty, combating discrimination and inequalities without leaving anyone behind is a key element; this is said by the Treaty on European Union itself, which states that external action will be based on the principle of universality and the indivisibility of human rights. The new cooperation instrument provides for more than EUR 32 billion for Africa, more than a third of the budget. We must, from this Parliament, be a guarantor that this budget is implemented by respecting and empowering LGTBI people. The Cotonou Agreement itself also provides that, if human rights are not respected, this may be grounds for breaking this Agreement. In breach of this, we should be this Parliament guaranteeing these rights. Defending human rights is defending LGTBI rights, without indivisibility.

name: Phil BENNION
text: – Mr President, Uganda is a country where the human rights of the LGBTI community have been stripped away by anti-gay legislation for a very long time. The country’s LGBTI community has a history of being harassed and silenced by the government and the Ugandan police. The new plan by the government is to reintroduce the ‘kill the gays’ bill from 2014. This bill criminalises not only the act of same-sex activities, it even makes it clear that anyone who is even involved in promotional and information dissemination also has to be criminalised. The bill will lead to witch-hunts, more harassment, violence and, as we have seen, even extrajudicial executions.  The international community cannot let this happen. We need to remind Uganda that the right to sexuality and to express one’s sexuality and freedom from discrimination is based on the universality of human rights and is guaranteed by international human rights law. Furthermore, the Ugandan Government has an obligation under the Cotonou Agreement, which calls for universal human rights to be respected.

name: Alice KUHNKE
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Five years ago, many of us drew a sigh of relief when uganda withdrew the proposal to impose the death penalty on homosexuals. Now the same heinous policy has been re-presented. This time we must act decisively.  EU development assistance to Uganda in 2014-2020 amounts to a whopping EUR 578 million. That's a lot of money. But this money is conditional. There are clear wordings in the agreement that human rights should be upheld. That is why we Greens are calling for the EU to distance itself clearly from homophobic developments in Uganda. Step by step, the crimes have become more serious. It's got to stop. Now.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Mr President, I am, of course, against the death penalty full- stop, but the fact that that was being considered for the crime of love is utterly outrageous. Let’s be clear: the criminalisation of homosexuality in any form legitimises homophobic hate and actually constitutes a death sentence for many people. I, of course, offer full solidarity to the victims in Uganda and the LGBTI activists in that region. But I do find it a little bit sickening, that some in this House sought to add to this resolution a bit of self-congratulations to the EU, as if we are some sort of a beacon of human rights excellence. We shouldn’t forget that we don’t have to go to Uganda to find appalling discrimination against LGBTI people. For many people in Europe, the inaction and complacency of the EU at the persistent and rising prejudice and hatred in our own Member States should also be listened to. Solidarity doesn’t stop outside our borders and should begin at home.

name: Seb DANCE
text: – Mr President, it’s humiliating enough to know that the marriage to the man I love is not possible in all of the 28 Member States of the European Union. It’s humiliating enough to know that there will be some in this House who don’t even believe I should have the right to that marriage, but, at the very least, I know that my life is not at risk when I walk the streets of the European Union, in most cases. Words have consequences, and the Minister Simon Lokodo, the so-called Ethics Minister in Uganda, should be utterly ashamed of himself, because what he is doing is trying to deflect from his government’s own failings and using LGBTI people as a scapegoat. I want to address directly LGBTI people in Uganda and in every country in the world that suffers under discrimination laws and prohibition. You are not the problem here. The problem is failing governments who are using you as a scapegoat. Stay strong, because you have the support in the solidarity of people here. This is a struggle throughout the world, not just in Africa, not just in Asia, this is a struggle everywhere and we share that struggle, and we stand with you. And repeal those colonial laws.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I want to thank the authors of this resolution and I want to thank everyone who has spoken, because the voice of the European Parliament is united and clear. A complete condemnation of the political reality in Uganda.  The law that has been put in place is absolutely scandalous, and it is probably not about you, but about the next European Commission, Commissioner. It is not possible to send European money to countries where a homosexual minority is being so madly bullied. This must have an impact on the development aid provided by the European Union to Uganda.  It has already been said by colleagues that the aid is not small at all, and we are sending money to governments that are considering punishing homosexual intercourse with the death penalty. Moreover, prisons in Uganda are full of gay activists, human rights activists, and we send our European money to such a country. This is really scandalous and I think that this resolution that we are adopting today must be a guide for the European Commission to change its practice and support for Uganda as a result.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Mimica, on Thursdays in the Strasbourg plenary we are debating human rights violations, and it is a moment of rare unanimity because, those of us present, are very motivated: committed against the death penalty, against all forms of discrimination, against the most ominous human rights violations... And all of this is mixed in this aberrant case of criminalization—with the threat of the death penalty—of homosexuality in Uganda.  Africa is the absolute priority of European foreign policy for good reasons, and also of development cooperation: it is the lion's part of the European humanitarian cooperation budget. But European diplomacy must be used thoroughly to remove these unacceptable human rights violations of criminalizing the right to love oneself for people of the same sex.  That is why we demand that the Cotonou Agreement be enforced, so that if there is a country that is completely incompatible with the cause of respect for the most basic human rights, that country will be excluded from the very large aid that the European Union invests in development cooperation and humanitarian aid; and it can't be for nothing.

name: Barbara Ann GIBSON
text: – Mr President, I’d like to ask a question of not only my colleagues, but all those listening. What gives you the right – any right: the right to live, to love, to work, to freedom, to health? What gives you your rights? And what gives anyone, any government, any religion, the right to take that away from you – to take away your human rights? By signing this resolution, by my vote today, and my continuing work as an activist, as an MEP in my own country and area, I say: No. You do not have the right. You can’t take away human rights of LGBTI people – in Uganda or anywhere. I urge this Parliament and people everywhere to join me in this fight in Uganda, in Europe, and in our home countries.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I join the condemns that have been made here today from my colleagues. Of course, brutal attacks on people who are just some are, in my opinion, completely unacceptable. And the behaviour of the Ugandan Government is unacceptable. If he indirectly supports these attacks, if he is changing the law and proposing a law to criminalise, even punish with the death penalty just because I am one, I think that is unacceptable in the twentieth century, not just in the twentieth century. It's a throwback to the Middle Ages.  In my opinion, our voice should be heard completely. I join in what my colleague Pospisil said. These decisions of ours, this indignation of ours, must be reflected in our policies, in our development aid. We must raise our voice to defend these human rights, and at the same time I will not forgive a remark made to the Czech Republic. We have come a long way, even in the 1960s homosexuality was punishable in our country. I firmly believe that the Czech Parliament will also take decisive steps in protecting equality of rights.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Mr President, the problem of the 21st century is respect for human rights, because if they are not respected, this century will not be at all. I note with concern that some countries are returning to the Middle Ages and that fundamental rights, such as the right to life, to education, to health, to express yourself freely, are being violated, as in a dark environment.  I call today on the future European Commission, the current Parliament and the Council to find a set of common measures and clear criteria so that such things do not happen again and to have a unified attitude when these rights are violated, either in the European or extra-European space, because, look at you, sometimes we see the straw in the eye of another than the beam in our eyes. It is time to have a firm attitude that this European Parliament, the new elected Parliament, together with the new Commission, will indeed make this 21st century a century in which human rights are respected.

name: Radka MAXOVÁ
text: – Mr President, I am very glad that the European Parliament has prepared a strong resolution against the adoption of legislation introducing the death penalty for different sexual orientations. I dare say that there is now a bit of a ball on the part of the European Commission, which should take a stand on this as the colleagues before me have said.  Different sexual orientation is not a crime. It's not stealing, it's not rape, it's not murder, it's not manslaughter. After all, intimidation, smourdating or threats of the death penalty for different sexual orientations is against the rules of the European Union, which speaks very loudly against any discrimination. I am glad that the European Parliament is in such a strong position and that we are sending a message to the people of the LGBTI community in Uganda that we stand behind them and that we will do our utmost not to punish them for the way they were born.

name: Radka MAXOVÁ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we are well aware that LGBTI people in Uganda have for many years faced discrimination and violence, including hate crimes. The latest personal comments expressed by a Ugandan State Minister regarding the possibility of presenting a new anti-homosexuality law to the Ugandan Parliament, with the possibility of imposing the death penalty against homosexuals, is a sad example of this harsh reality. The prompt official reactions from the Ugandan Government and the Office of the President – also transmitted through diplomatic channels to the EU delegation and Member States’ ambassadors – have since then confirmed, without hesitation, that such a law is not in preparation. Therefore, we should consider this comment as highly concerning but not reflective of the official policy of the Government of Uganda. At the same time, it is clear that such a public statement from a Cabinet Minister of the Ugandan Government could spark regrettable reactions and further discrimination, hostility or violence against LGBTI people in Uganda. The European Union encourages states to take all necessary steps – in particular, legislative or administrative measures, to ensure that sexual orientation, gender identity or sexual characteristics may not under any circumstances be the basis for criminal penalties – in particular executions, which the EU strongly opposes in any circumstances. Discrimination against LGBTI persons undermines the most basic human rights enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. I can assure you that all our services, and particularly our EU delegation in Kampala, are closely following the situation and will convey our messages, including this Parliament’s declaration, at the appropriate levels.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, Thursday 24 October 2019.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Egypt (2019/2880(RSP)). Before the start of the debate, I would like to inform you that, in order to speak with the catch-the-eye procedure or to ask a question with a blue card, you can use both the usual registration method and the new electronic registration system. For this reason, I would ask you to always bring the voting card with you. If you wish to register for the catch-the-eye process, please start now without waiting for the end of the discussion.

name: Hannah NEUMANN
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which In September, thousands of people took to the streets in Egypt. And that was new: they have taken to the streets all over the country, they have fought against corruption, they have fought against corruption, they have lost the money that is being lent to the country and the citizens for the construction of roads, of schools, of hospitals, and that it is moving far too slowly. The regime violently crushed the protest, and 4,300 people were arrested, many of them children. Hundreds have disappeared, human rights activists are still being targeted, social media and messenger services are being monitored. The message is clear: Al-Sisi does not tolerate criticism of his rule, and unfortunately it arrives. Human rights activists today only dare to talk about violence in exile. And what does the EU do? She is silent. It transfers budget support to the government, and Member States continue to export surveillance technology and weapons. This week, for the first time, I was jointly responsible for a motion for a resolution, and I can tell you that the negotiations on this resolution were not easy, because we all agreed on really important consequences and thus got to the fore. And in the end, all those responsible agreed, and I am very proud of that. Because we say one thing very clearly: yes, Egypt is a partner of the European Union, but we no longer want to be accomplices of this regime. That means ending business as usual with Al-Sisi and freedom for the protesters. And, more specifically, no more espionage technology in the hands of this regime. It is not acceptable for us in Europe to make money from it. In other words, no more blank cheques for EU funds to the regime, but a review of budget support and the strengthening of civil society. And – and this goes to the Commission – it is finally clear in diplomatic negotiations and statements! Ladies and gentlemen, I have my suitcase outside and I am now flying straight to Egypt and I am telling you: I would really like to take this resolution with me, because I know that it gives hope to many people – and yes, some of them also headaches. Anyone who tramples on the rights of their citizens must face consequences. Let us send this signal to Egypt today in all clarity!

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Author. – Mr President, once again we are talking about Egypt. And why? For the brutal crackdown on social mobilizations. While Al-Sisi met at the United Nations with world leaders, thousands of people were arrested. Some missing and some tortured.  The European Union looks the other way as Member States sell military equipment that is being used to suppress the Egyptian popular movement. It is not a question of the European Union protecting human rights in Egypt. We don't even ask for that much anymore, we just say that the European Union cannot continue to lay down a dictatorship like Egypt's. And that is why we demand that the Commission's budgetary support be terminated and that its assistance be limited only to supporting civil society; suspend discussions for a trade agreement with Egypt, until human rights are respected; a real and effective arms embargo; and the end of cooperation in migration policies. In short, ladies and gentlemen, Commission, we demand to take action and not cooperate with a dictatorship so that our words do not remain wet paper, so that we do not have to talk about Egypt again in plenary. That action be taken and that human rights are respected.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: author. – Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, recent events in Egypt have shown how little space for freedom of expression and peaceful assembly is left in the country. We witness the disproportionate use of force against protesters, unlawful behaviour against human rights defenders and restrictions on the activities of civil society organisations. What worries me most is that Egypt’s leadership is increasingly using the fight against terrorism as an internal policy instrument to stop public criticism and to silence its political opponents. Dialogue between the country’s leadership and society is possible only if the former meets citizens’ expectations and embarks on reforms in the different sectors so needed in Egypt. From the EU side, we must increase our attention along with financial support for Egypt’s human rights defenders and civil society organisations.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Author. Mr President, since 20 September, it has been said, anti-government demonstrations have been taking place throughout Egypt, in all cities. The Egyptian authorities arbitrarily arrested more than 4,000 people. Among them, it is said, journalists, lawyers, human rights defenders who find themselves imprisoned, burdened with heavy charges, including acts of terrorism. Those arrested do not have access to their lawyer or the opportunity to see their families. Some are tortured and denied access to health care.  The arrests are part of a wider crackdown in Egypt, where citizens' democratic rights are being violated, including the right to protest and the right to freedom of expression.  The European Parliament, in this resolution, urges the Egyptian authorities to release human rights activists. I will quote a few to put faces: Ramy Shaath; Alaa Abdel Fattah, Asmaa Daabes, Israa Abdel Fattah. They and thousands of them are now in prison.  We condemn the actions of the Egyptian authorities and call on Egypt to ensure egypt's democratic transition. We call on the Union to completely review its relationship with Egypt, as long as human rights improvements are not granted. This requires the reorientation of the Commission's budgets in favour of strengthening civil society. But it also means that the European Union and the Member States must stop granting arms export licences, which are now used against civilians.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. – Mr President, I am very happy that I have cooperated in the creation of this resolution, which calls on Egypt to be open and open to the world.  The criticism that is being made against the leaders of Egypt is not a crushing criticism, but it is a criticism that concerns specific points that are wrong in Egypt. Yes, we have accomplished a lot as the European Union, and we cannot say that all aid has gone into the hands of some terrorists or some human rights groups there. With European Union money, hospitals are being built there, the social system is being strengthened and we are really taking care of the neediest.  On the other hand, however, we need an open dialogue with the Egyptian Government on human rights violations. We cannot ignore egypt's failure to respect international obligations, including the right to a fair trial or the right to adequate legal protection for those who are vulnerable groups. Human rights violations are systematically taking place in Egypt. We could see this in the demonstrations, when many people disappeared without Egypt answering where these people were. And we will ask Egypt for open answers to our questions. We must also mention some of our Citizens of the European Union who have disappeared in Egypt, and to this day we have not received an explanation from the Egyptian authorities as to their location. Indeed, Egypt needs to change its policy towards those who criticise it.  Yes, let us support society, support civil society and be tough on those things where we can be, for example, on the issue of human rights and freedom of expression. There I think that, as the European Union, we still have huge gaps.

name: Seán KELLY
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa PPE. – A Uachtaráin, bhíomar thíos an bóthar seo cheana féin. Go háirithe, cuimhneoidh Feisirí ó mo thír féin ar an gcás a bhain le Ibrahim Halawa agus an tuarascáil a bhí againn sa Pharlaimint seo faoi. Thug na Feisirí go léir tacaíocht dúinn maidir leis sin.  B’shin leaid óg a cuireadh i bpríosún san Éigipt. D’fhulaing sé a lán foréigin agus ní raibh aon triail aige. I ndáiríre, bhí seans ann go gcuirfí chun báis é. Ach tar éis na tuarascála a bhí againne, chun a gceart a thabhairt d’údaráis na hÉigipte, ligeadh saor é agus tá sé ar ais inár dtír anois agus níl sé ag cur isteach ar mhuintir na hÉigipte.  Dá bhrí sin, tá an rud céanna ag tarlú anois, go háirithe le cúpla seachtain anuas - 4300 duine curtha i bpríosún gan aon triail. Daoine áirithe imithe gan tásc ná tuairisc orthu agus 111 ógánach i measc na ndaoine atá i bpríosún. Caithfimid an brú céanna a chur ar mhuintir na hÉigipte éisteacht linn agus triail a thabhairt dóibh siúd nó iad a ligint saor.  Tuigimid go bhfuil an Éigipt faoi bhrú ag sceimhlitheoirí de gach saghas agus caithfimid cabhrú leo troid ina gcoinne siúd. Ag an am céanna, ba chóir dóibh na cearta daonna atá ag daoine a aithint. Go háirithe freisin, mar Chríostaí atá i ngrúpa Críostaí - PPE - caithfidh siad cearta a thabhairt do na Críostaithe atá san Éigipt freisin, agus má dhéanann siad san, is féidir linn dul ar aghaidh agus níos mó cúnaimh a thabhairt dóibh.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, in what some already call "the autumn of the peoples", Egyptians took to the streets in protest against impoverishment, social injustices, corruption and repression in the country.  The arbitrary arrests of some 4,300 people following these peaceful demonstrations are in line with the actions of an authoritarian government that does not respect freedom of expression and association and that uses intimidation, promotes the trial of civilians in military courts, in a country where forced disappearances, death penalty convictions, including children are reported , and where the principles of democracy and the rule of law are permanently brought into question. The European Union cannot remain indifferent. It must support civil society and use all means at its disposal to pressure Egypt to respect human rights. And Member States should implement the measures announced in 2013: suspension of any supply of technological equipment, weapons and other assets that may serve internal repression, torture, or the application of the death penalty.

name: Irina VON WIESE
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, I would like to highlight just one case: the case of Ibrahim Ezz El-Din, who is an Egyptian human rights defender and a researcher specialising in housing rights at the Egyptian Commission for Rights and Freedom (ECRF). He was arrested on 11 June near his home in Cairo and taken to an unknown location. Since then, his family have not had any contact with him, the local police station denies his presence within their premises, and the Attorney General has not responded to numerous queries. Ibrahim’s arrest is believed to be linked to his criticism of government housing and urban planning policies, including shanty towns and evictions. He is the fifth staff member of ECRF to be arrested since 2016 as part of a crackdown on human rights defenders in Egypt. I urge Parliament to recognise this as one of many urgent cases in Egypt and call on the Egyptian authorities to take all necessary measures for the safe release of Ibrahim Ezz El—Din and so many other human rights defenders in Egypt.

name: Mounir SATOURI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, first of all, I want to pay tribute to the extraordinary courage of human rights defenders and to have a thought for the 60,000 political prisoners held in Egypt. This simple figure makes you dizzy and reminds us of the urgency to act.  I hear that the Commission would have another urgency in terms of numbers. It would consider disbursing tens and tens of millions of euros in budgetary aid to Egypt before the end of the year. This would be an act of direct assistance to the Egyptian government granted unconditionally. One could, by simply extrapolating, describe this act as direct aid to the French government, because it is now proven that France sells arms and military equipment to Egypt, in clear violation of the Council's conclusions.  Mrs Mogherini, your guilty silence makes you complicit. The Union's overt inconsistencies make it an inaudible player on the international stage. Yet we have the means to be up to the task. You can reserve financial aid to civil society, you can decide on targeted sanctions and, most importantly, you must enforce the arms embargo.

name: Elena LIZZI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, when we talk about the violation of human rights in Egypt, we must remember in this Parliament that, almost four years after the death of Giulio Regeni, my fellow Friulian researcher, the Egyptian authorities have not yet revealed the truth about his death.  Furthermore, national and international mobilizations, including those of this Parliament, have not yet produced results, with the resolutions of 10 March 2016 and 13 December 2018. While promoting truth and justice is also the duty of the European Union, it is also a duty to guarantee and protect the rights of its citizens, outside the Schengen area. Was everything done for Giulio Regeni?  Let us remember that the European Union is Egypt's first economic partner and its main source of foreign investment, so much so that the European Union's bilateral assistance to Egypt, under the European Neighbourhood Instrument, amounts to around EUR 500 million for the period 2017-2020; that Egypt is an important interlocutor and a key country for stability in the Mediterranean area, given its geopolitical position and the presence of a long border in the desert, which makes it difficult to control flows, people and goods; - the confrontation between Egypt and the Eu ropean Union must promote respect for and protection of the rights and freedoms of the individual, because the stability of a country runs parallel to the protection of individual freedoms, respect for the value of life and the rule of law; that the wave of repression, the tense climate and international criticism could threaten the very stability of Egypt and therefore of the whole area of North Africa and could involve Europe, with disastrous consequences.  Also in the light of the recent resumption of dialogue between the Cairo and Rome prosecutors, Europe must encourage the government of al-Sisi to reassure the international community about respect for human rights in Egypt, so that this effort can also open a window of opportunity to reveal the truth about the atrocious death of the young Friulian.

name: Nicola PROCACCINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is right that this House should support the defence of civil rights in Egypt.  I agree with the call for respect for the various religions, particularly the Christian religion, and I agree with the call for greater cooperation with the Italian authorities in identifying those responsible for the brutal murder of Giulio Regeni. However, this is not the first time that I have found myself expressing my disappointment at the Manichean approach with which this Parliament expresses its political positions. It is the method that identifies the demonization of this or that enemy as the simple solution to very complex problems.  That is why I would like to highlight the more balanced and fair approach of the motion tabled by Mrs Fotyga of the Group of the European People's Party (ECR): a condemnation of the al-Sisi Government cannot and must not be seen as a closure towards a key economic partner, but above all in the context of the fight against Islamic terrorism.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, how many activists, how many journalists, how many members of minorities, students, NGOs, how many women, how many minors persecuted. It is difficult to find areas in which the violence of the Egyptian Government, whether more or less structured, explicit or otherwise organised, has not broken down and let us remember that the death penalty is still in force. Many are awaiting the death sentence. We are well aware that the internal situation is not easy, that Egypt, a partner that remains important, is going through a complex phase, that the neighbourhood is restless, but that is why we cannot remain silent, deny or turn our heads. Egypt cannot fall victim to extremism, but at the same time it cannot remain hostage to pervasive and constant repression, accompanied, in addition, by discrimination and defamatory campaigns. The embarrassing silence on the case of the researcher Giulio Regeni is emblematic, swallowed up in a gurgling of silences, misreaches, falsehoods, reluctance. This well-stigmatised issue in the resolution remains a heavy and disturbing shadow over the country. Exports of weapons to be blocked, really and immediately, funds allocated to be frozen if there is no respect for conditionality: this serves to be consistent, this serves to have truth and justice for Giulio Regeni.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are once again denouncing the serious violations of human rights and fundamental freedoms in Egypt, which show no sign of diminishing with arbitrary detention, the use of torture and repression.  We said this in my report on the Arab spring referendum adopted last April.  We can no longer tolerate close cooperation with countries that do not respect our fundamental values or that do not cooperate with us in judicial investigations involving citizens of the European Union. I am thinking in particular of the case of Giulio Regeni, which has not yet been resolved for more than three years. President Conte reiterated this to al-Sisi himself last August. Italy does not stop demanding the truth. The Cairo prosecutor's office has made its way to a new meeting with the Rome prosecutor's office. We will see how willing they are to cooperate or how much a lark mirror will remain.  We denounce the climate of impunity and the absence of a credible investigation, the refusal of the Egyptian authorities to provide Italy with the documents and information necessary for a rapid, transparent and impartial investigation, in line with international obligations. We call for the extradition of the five suspects in the case to Italy as soon as possible, as requested by the Rome public prosecutor's office. We won't stop until we have truth for Giulio Regeni.

name: Jan-Christoph OETJEN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which 2011 was a historic turning point in Egypt's history. Millions of Egyptians have taken to the streets with the hope of more freedom, democracy, respect for human rights and also a better economic situation. Eight years later, however, the reality in Egypt is quite different: the situation of freedom of the press, freedom of expression and human rights has deteriorated, and the harshness of the repression under President Al-Sisi is even harsher than under former ruler Husni Mubarak. Amnesty International reports that systematic torture and other abuses by the authorities continue in Egyptian prisons. That is unacceptable! In response to the recent anti-government demonstrations, the regime has recently arbitrarily arrested 4 300 people; of these, 3 000 are still in pre-trial detention. Many report torture. Human rights activists are targeted by the police, some simply disappear, fundamental rights are trampled underfoot. We can't keep watching. That is why it is time for us to limit financial aid to Egypt to direct aid to the population. That is our mission now. We must act now!

name: Adam BIELAN
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Egypt is a key country for stability in the Middle East and north Africa. It is an extremely important economic partner for the European Union. It plays a very important role in migration processes. Let us recall that Egypt has accepted a great many refugees from Syria. Above all, it is an extremely important country in the ongoing war on terrorism. The Egyptian authorities are fighting Islamic terrorists in the Sinai Peninsula very hard. Over the past year, a wave of demonstrations has swept through Egypt. More than two and a half thousand people were arrested. The Authorities of the European Union should not be passive and should protest, especially against political arrests. I am pleased that the European Union is doing this, but the reality is not black and white. Among the organizers of the demonstration were very many people associated with the Muslim Brotherhood. Among the participants in these demonstrations were many extremists associated with Isis. I am pleased that President al-Sisi is doing a lot to protect Egyptian Christians. But these efforts are still insufficient. According to Open Doors, 108 Egyptian Christians were killed in 2017 only. I appeal to the President... (The President has received the speaker's vote.)

name: Ben HABIB
text: – Mr President, when President el-Sisi became President of Egypt in 2014 he had a basic contract with the people of Egypt, which was to deliver stability, security and economic prosperity, in return for near total control. It was a very similar contract to the one that the EU has taken upon itself for the people of the European Union. That contract is all well and good for as long as stability, security and economic prosperity continue, and like the European Union, the wheels came off in Egypt, and his response to the wheels coming off the economy was to tighten his grip on power, to tighten his grip on the people. And the European Union's response is exactly the same – it wishes to tighten its grip every time something goes wrong. And here's a warning. Do not tighten your grip anymore. We may be a long way from Egypt at the moment, but we will fast catch up. Loosen your grip.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, I rise once again to speak about human rights in Egypt. El-Sisi promised stability, security and economic prosperity to the people of Egypt. He delivered none of this, but a crackdown on political opponents, media and civil society. Now Trump may be willing to turn a blind eye to the human rights abuses in Egypt, but we are not. According to Amnesty International, 4 300 people, including women and minors, have been arrested since the start of the protests in September. It is outrageous. So I call for an immediate and unconditional release of all prisoners, in particular Ramy Shaabh and Mohamed Masry. My question, though, to the Commissioner: what answers do you have? Many colleagues have referred to the case of Giulio Regeni, a Cambridge University student from Italy, who went missing in Cairo whilst undertaking research for his PhD. Ten days later, his body was found with evidence of the most severe torture. Almost four years on, we have no answers from el-Sisi and the Egyptian Government. So what are you doing to review the billions of euros we send to Egypt through the European Neighbourhood Instrument, and what is the Commission proposing to cut back in order to get some answers from Egypt?

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Author. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Egypt is very important to us, because stability in this country is in the interests of our countries. Instability is very likely to mean hundreds of thousands, maybe millions, of refugees arriving in Europe, so let us keep our fingers crossed for Egypt. Of course, it is necessary to demand that the young people who are demonstrating are not in prison, while it is important to know that the Islamic Extremists are behind the organisation of these demonstrations and that these people are clearly treating these demonstrators as cannon fodder for the fight against power.  Egypt has accepted refugees from Syria, so it is worth remembering, but here in the European Parliament we should first of all talk about defending the rights of Christians in this country. It must be said very clearly here that the Egyptian Government has done a great deal in this direction, but there are still attacks on our brothers and sisters in the faith, so the Egyptian authorities must be very strongly supported in this regard in order to keep The Coptic Christians safe in Egypt. In a word, let us show our solidarity with the Egyptian authorities, which are part of the stability of this country, while demanding the release of political prisoners.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I want to support this motion for a resolution, I agree with my colleagues who have criticised the human rights situation in Egypt. What General Sísi's regime is demonstrating is hardly defensible, although I perceive that Egypt is a key partner of the European Union, but we cannot turn a blind eye to the fact that human rights are being totally trampled on in Egypt.  I have spent my whole life as a former Minister of Justice dealing with the death penalty, and it must be stated and supplemented by the list of human rights violations in Egypt and by the fact that the death penalty has begun to be significantly abused under General Sísi's regime. In the last five years, 3,000 people have been sentenced to death and the sentence has been enforced. There was no due process, juveniles and women were sentenced to death. Unfortunately, this is a signal that the human rights situation in Egypt is deteriorating. This thing, too, this "partisan thing" shows how difficult it is today in Egypt and how human rights are being trampled on by the regime there.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Mr President, 'it is enough for good people to do nothing for evil to triumph', warns Edmund Burke. What the situation in Egypt warns us is that the boundary between democracy and dictatorship is extremely fine. But what worries me today in the plenary of the European Parliament is that for years they have known about certain things and they have not been resolved. We can lament about human rights violations, we can come up with beautiful resolutions, but without concrete measures, things cannot change for the better.  That is why I am asking you today for some strong points for the future Commission to take into account – the release of prisoners who are politically convicted and the end of this death penalty, which has nothing to look for in the 21st century.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Mr President, I think there is actually a sad irony in the familiarity of this resolution. Parts of it are a copy and paste of the resolution that was passed almost a year ago, and yet the situation on the ground in Egypt is actually deteriorating. I find a lot of double speak in here, because to go forward we need to look backwards, and while the Resolution expresses European Parliament’s support for the aspirations of the Egyptian people to establish a free and stable, prosperous, inclusive democratic society, we have to remind ourselves that the EU congratulated el-Sisi on coming to power. We should remind ourselves that the first democratically-elected civilian President – Morsi – was ousted in a coup, kept in solitary confinement and is now dead. So triggering resolutions once a year is not good enough. We have to look at our actions, and working with the likes of Egypt and Saudi Arabia, calling for a stronger partnership on migration and border controls, makes us complicit. Egypt does what it does because of the involvement of Member States of the European Union in giving them arms and giving them back-up.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Mr President, President Trump recently called the Egyptian President el-Sisi ‘my favourite dictator’. The UK is Egypt’s largest investor and France is Egypt’s largest supplier of weapons. The US, the UK and France will turn a blind eye to human rights every time it suits them. Let’s not forget that before el-Sisi became President, he presided over the single largest massacre of unarmed protesters in modern history in 2013.  El-Sisi is a brutal dictator. Do the French have any problems selling him weapons? No. Do the French have any problems selling weapons to the Saudis who are committing genocide in Yemen? No. Does the EU do anything about it? No. This European Union has sanctions, which are a form of terrorism, against Venezuela, Syria, Iran. You do business with murderers. What’s going on with you?

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, in September thousands of protesters took to the streets in Egypt – from Cairo to Alexandria to Suez – in response to corruption allegations against President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi. Since then, el-Sisi has overseen what human rights groups say is an unprecedented crackdown on dissent that’s led to the detention of over 3 000 people. Over 100 of these are children – some as young as 11, several detained on their way home from school. Detainees are added to a single charge sheet, accused of aiding a terrorist group, spreading false information, misuse of social media and participation in unauthorised protests.  Once again we remind the Egyptian Government that under international law people have a right to protest peacefully and a right to express their opinions, including on social media.

name: Julie WARD
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the European Union has a clear interest in Egypt’s long-term stability and security, and it is our firm conviction that this can only be achieved if human rights are fully implemented and upheld, in line with the country’s international commitments, its own legal provisions and the partnership priorities jointly agreed with the European Union. The European Union continuously recalls the need for Egypt to improve the situation of civil and political rights, including freedom of expression, both online and offline. The European Union emphasises the importance of respecting fundamental freedoms of peaceful assembly and association and the rights of human rights defenders. The European Union welcomes the passing of a new NGO law which replaces the much—criticised 2017 law. It is crucial that it is implemented in a way that allows civil society to work freely and that all restrictive measures for human rights defenders under the foreign funding case are lifted. Large numbers of arrests took place in the wake of the 20 September protests. Since then, arrests have been extended to those that did not take part in the protests. It is particularly concerning that arrests targeted politicians, human rights defenders, lawyers and journalists, most of whom are detained on terrorism-related charges. Prominent examples are Esraa Abdel Fattah, Mahinour el-Masry, Alaa Abdel Fattah and Mohamed el—Baqer. These events take place against an otherwise positive recent record on social and economic rights. The European Union is deeply concerned about reports of mistreatments, torture, forced disappearances and poor detention conditions. Detainees should be treated in line with international standards. There is a clear need for accountability for all forms of pressure, harassment and violence against human rights defenders and civilians seeking to exercise their right to protest peacefully. The European Union recalls that permitting space to varying views and for the expression of justified grievances will be beneficial, and civil society should thus not be subject to such measures as asset-freezes or travel bans. We are continuously engaged in bilateral dialogue with Egypt within the framework of our partnership.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debate.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the proposed new criminal law in Indonesia (2019/2881(RSP)). I have been asked to inform you again that you can register the blue card with a hand signal as well as electronically and that you can also register electronically for spontaneous speeches now, and not at the end of the debate before we come to the spontaneous speeches. However, this requires that you have the voting card with you and inserted it.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: author. – Mr President, Indonesia is a very important partner of the EU. It is extremely important also for my country, Poland. All our concerns that are provided in our ECR draft resolutions are being raised in the course of the human rights dialogue of the EEAS (European External Action Service) with Indonesia. I sincerely ask my colleagues – parliamentarians – to adopt the amendment I tabled concerning a Pole, a vagabond, a traveller, who was by mistake accused of high treason and sentenced to five years in prison just because of his love for Papuan culture. I sincerely ask to raise this question, also on behalf of all Poles.

name: Idoia VILLANUEVA RUIZ
text: Author. – Mr President, in recent years we have seen a worrying trend in the tightening of criminal laws, almost always in two ways: the persecution of the political dissident and the criminalisation of the proposal itself; with different magnitudes, in different places, but with these aspects, as is the case in Indonesia today.  This reform in Indonesia is clear about its enemies: it speaks of Marxist-Leninist ideas, non-religious groups, expanding alleged crimes of blasphemy, which already exist in the country, and also criminalizes women who exercise their right to abortion and LGTBI people, as well as adultery.  It's a country that hasn't been accountable for its past yet. In 2008, dictator Haji Suharto, who has the murder behind him in 1965, of between 600 billion and two million people died behind him. The pursuit of political dissent comes from afar.  And what should the European Union do? We are clear: it must be firm in defending its values, firm in the defence of human rights, in Europe and in the world. We fill our mouths talking about feminism, pluralism and freedom, but we forget it very soon when free trade arrives.

name: Katalin CSEH
text: author. – Mr President, Indonesia has long been a valued partner of the EU, with strong political, economic and trade ties. After recent elections in the country, a new political cycle has just begun, with a parliament and a president who is eager to finish reforms that were started decades ago. However, this proposed new criminal code had been a very controversial element of the process. Thousands of Indonesians took to the streets in protest, forcing decision-makers to postpone the vote on the new bill. And we are thankful for this decision, as it allows time for vital consultation. I also think that this is the right time for the European Parliament to weigh in in the debate and stand up for the principles of basic human rights and democratic principles. This resolution focuses on the most contentious elements. Around 20 articles are considered highly alarming, as they discriminate against women, the LGBTI community and religious minorities. Other provisions would criminalise contraception, extramarital sex or even criticising the president. If adopted in its current form, this new bill would represent a clear setback for human rights, free speech and democracy in Indonesia. We hope that authorities will recognise their historic role in establishing a criminal code that serves to solidify the rule of law instead of fuelling dangerous social divides. Therefore it’s urgent... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Marianne VIND
text: asks. Mr President! Indonesia's new penal code goes against all our democratic values and so against human rights. We can never stand by when discrimination against women and minorities is enshrined in a law and fundamental rights are disregarded. It is therefore extremely important that indonesia should really listen to the concrete proposals contained in the European Parliament resolution.  We have been careful to keep the tone constructive and welcoming. Amendments have now been tabled to the resolution in which it is intended to mention two EU citizens who have been imprisoned in Indonesian prisons. These are certainly terrible situations, but specific names do not belong in this context. In the resolution, we condemn Indonesia's continued use of the death penalty. It's clear.  Zooming in on individual citizens, however, will dilute the broad resolution, which otherwise puts an important focus on problematic elements of the criminal code. At worst, the Indonesian Government will see the whole decision as a cover for the release of EU citizens, rather than a real concern for the millions of Indonesians who will live under the new penal code.  I urge everyone to vote in favour of the resolution, but vote against Amendments Nos 1, 4 and 5.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. – Mr President, Commissioner, in general, we would say that, within South-East Asia, we regard Indonesia as a stable partner that has and adheres to certain democratic principles.  It was all the more surprising that, in reforming the criminal code, which was many years old, a number of points came into its wording that we find that they do not in any way reflect the long-term development in this country and actually rank Indonesia among the extreme countries that want to violate fundamental human rights to which this state has long subscribed. We are therefore very pleased that, in recent months, when the President, the Government and political leaders have changed, these negotiations on a new form of the Criminal Code have been suspended and that dialogue has also begun with other countries, including the European Union, on its form.  I am happy and optimistic about this, and I believe that it will in no way pass in this form in which this code was proposed, and that Indonesia will once again show that it is one of the stable democratic partners who build their future on respect for human rights and will not reinstate the death penalty or other excesses involving either sexual or religious minorities. I think that during my time as an MEP, I have had the opportunity to negotiate several times with indonesian officials, and I think that this openness and the effort to listen to each other is an important element here so that the situation that is now in Indonesia never happens again.

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Indonesia is the fourth most populated country in the world (265 million), largely a Muslim country but with huge diversity in terms of ethnic minorities, religion, languages, culture. At the same time, it’s a country that’s making very good progress and one that we can have a much closer partnership with into the future. And as a member of the ASEAN delegation and of the International Trade Committee, I would hope that over the next five years we could move, perhaps, towards having a free trade agreement with Indonesia. This is a good time to debate this issue, because often we say to ourselves: what effect do our urgencies have? Well this is very timely, because the Criminal Code, which we have difficulty with, is now going through the process of ratification in Indonesia. But, as it has been pointed out, as a result of protests – which are allowed in a functioning democracy, which Indonesia is (we must recognise that), the President decided to postpone ratification. So this is very timely for us to outline issues which we are not happy with. And indeed, which do not comply with international norms in relation to women’s rights, religious minorities, LGTBTI rights, political ideologies, reproductive health and the death penalty. And I think it will be good for us, especially with the new Commission, if we were to send a delegation to Indonesia to discuss these issues. I myself, in my capacity as a rapporteur for the renewable energy file, met a huge delegation who came here to Europe last year in relation to palm oil. So there is ongoing dialogue and I think we could come together and discuss these issues and move rapidly to a closer relationship.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: on behalf of the S&D group – Mr President, there are three things that we are extremely concerned about at the moment about the situation in Indonesia.  I speak primarily of the law of blasphemy - it is incredible that in the 21st century one can be condemned for religious faith; those abusive laws against women – hard years of imprisonment and the restriction of fundamental rights in terms of the purpose of the body and what each must do with regard to health issues. And the long list of those on the podium of those who are sentenced to death is another issue that needs to be considered.  I believe that firm measures are needed: the first two points (blasphemy law and the law against women) must be suspended, and at least one moratorium must be introduced at this time with regard to the death penalty in this country. And I hope that the future European Commission will resolve this, and the European Parliament, through all its members, must support this.

name: Shaffaq MOHAMMED
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, I’m speaking on this matter because of the fundamental importance of human rights across the world and in particular the role we, as the European Parliament, can play. A few weeks ago, myself and others stood on the steps of the Parliament in Brussels to celebrate International Safe Abortion Day. The world has come a long way in recognising the rights that women have over their bodies. But the journey is far from over. Unfortunately, and sadly, the new Criminal Code in Indonesia is another backward step on that journey. Human Rights Watch has said that the Indonesian draft Criminal Code is not just bad for women, minorities and gender minorities but for all Indonesians. The European Union has a loud voice, and we should use that loud voice to continue on that journey of equality. We must be clear: gender equality can never be achieved if only half the population has autonomy over their bodies. Gender equality goes to the heart of human rights, and we must fight for those rights.

name: Alice KUHNKE
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The proposal put forward by the Indonesian Government is a proposal for a policy that violates fundamental rights and freedoms. The law limits opportunities for women, for LGBTQ people and for religious minorities. It also limits the space for people who want to fight for the rights of others.  For us Greens, it goes without saying that what is now going on affects Indonesia's relationship with the EU. We therefore call on the Commission to clearly remind the Indonesian Government of what human rights are and that it is a fundamental duty of any government to defend civil rights and protect minorities from persecution and discrimination.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work he has Indonesia was seen by many as a model country of liberal Islam – no longer: interference with democratic freedom of expression and new crimes such as insulting the president – more than the apparent departure from Western libertinism – we also reproach. The Indonesian penal code seems to have been put on hold for the time being, but it raises quite interesting questions. People around the world do not share Western freedom of movement, nor does the suppression of the religious into the purely private, or the inflationary expansion of charters of fundamental rights far beyond individual protection against an overpowering state. That is their right.  Thanks to Mrs Merkel, however, the world is now coming to Europe without overturning its traditional values. The EU imports conflicts of values. Imported values then collide with domestic culture, political over-correctness, and decontaminated secularization – parallel societies thrive. The philosopher Isaiah Berlin calls such conflicts "value pluralism" and sees no compensation. The realist Hegel sees solutions only in the right of the strongest. Both, however, warn against social experiments.  The Green Cohn-Bendit is different. He writes: "When truly foreign cultures meet," "the conflict is permanent. The multicultural society is hard, fast, cruel and little in solidarity, it is marked by considerable social imbalances" and "has a tendency to move into a diversity of groups and communities and to lose its cohesion and the binding nature of its values". Indonesia is not primarily our problem, but it is a picture-stormer like Cohn-Bendit, who long simbly for a gutted, unsolidarity-free society without internal cohesion – for Indonesia and also for us.

name: Charlie WEIMERS
text: On the other: The ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Indonesia's criminal law dates back to colonial times and needs reform. Unfortunately, the proposal for a reformed criminal law does not meet international standards. The recent trend towards Islamism is unfortunately reflected in the bill that has been tabled in their parliament. The proposed law can de facto be interpreted as recognising sharia. Indonesia has hundreds of local Sharia courts that discriminate against women and religious and sexual minorities and which, of course, also restrict freedom of expression.  The proposed law extends existing legislation on blasphemy, a law that discriminates against non-Sunni Muslim minorities. More than 150 people have so far been convicted of blasphemy, including a Christian governor in Jakarta. When a country embraces Islamism, europe must mark that the choice is between partnership with us in the free world or sharia.

name: Mislav KOLAKUŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, the European Union is one of the greatest economic and political powers in the world. We take it for the right to share lessons with third countries, however, the way we do it is wrong.  We produce resolutions that are extremely mild and if the countries we address do not comply with our resolutions, nothing happens. That's what we're hurting ourselves with. We're damaging our influence and reputation.  We need to ensure an order that will be completely clear and always consistent. First comes the resolution, after that goes the warning and then the sanctions go. These sanctions and warnings must always be consistent because then when we send a specific resolution to a particular government, it will be known what the consequence will be.

name: Isabel WISELER-LIMA
text: Mr President, the new penal code in Indonesia is at the origin of this resolution, and it echoes student protests throughout Indonesia and mass protests in West Papua.  We want to express our support for the opposition to this new code because it criminalizes the elements that affect the identity of the person, his private sphere, which affect the freedom to think and believe, the freedom to dispose of his body, and this in an enlightened way.  We must denounce these facts and the repressive measures put in place. All the more so because, in reverse, a much-disputed law passed in September removes powers from the National Commission for the Eradication of Corruption. Now, we are in the realm of public life, where laws must be restrictive, guarantee equality for all before the law and guarantee the rule of law.  Finally, I would like to highlight the positive relationship between the European Union and Indonesia, namely the cooperation partnership and the annual human rights dialogues. We look forward, particularly in the context, to the human rights dialogue that will take place this year in November.

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: – Mr President, the European Union has a Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Indonesia in force since 2014, and now we have this situation on the table: a new penal code to replace the current one, with articles that blatantly violate the rights of women, religious, sexual minorities, freedom of expression and association.  We also have legislation that greatly weakens the anti-corruption framework in Indonesia. And I ask you in all honesty: is it not time to adopt Magnitsky legislation at European level? And does the fact that we close our eyes not make us complicit in the blatant and repeated abuses in these third countries with which we continue to have economic partnerships and agreements, does it not make us complicit with dictators whose money continues to enter the European Union?  And I would like to ask my colleagues one more question: in the Renew resolution there was a paragraph that referred to freedom of the press and the importance of journalists not being physically abused. This paragraph no longer exists in the common resolution.  Where is our honesty, dear colleagues?

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I am very happy that we are also addressing the issue of the quality of criminal law in the human rights bloc, because the quality of criminal law in a given country very much reflects whether the regime, the state, respects human rights or not.  And the proposal that colleagues are criticising here really needs to be properly criticised, because it really has nothing to do with the modern concept of criminal law, which is being debated by the Indonesian Parliament. It has already been said, there are provisions that violate the rights of sexual minorities, the rights of women to abortion, the right of religious minorities to express themselves freely under the guise of blasphemy, and so on.  In general, the law is hardly acceptable, because criminal law, if it is to be a reflection of the rule of law, must be lawful. It must be made clear what is and is not a criminal offence. And that is not what this law says, it is very vague and, in fact, if it passes, the Indonesian Government and the judiciary will be able to abuse it and choose what is a criminal offence. So our position is correct and dismissive.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, there are more than eighteen problematic articles within the proposed Penal Code in Indonesia that could seriously limit a wide range of civil liberties. There are proposed articles that are harmful to women, to LGBTI persons and religious minorities, and articles against free speech. These articles do not comply with international human rights norms and they do not stand up to international scrutiny.
