No parliament should regulate an individual’s private life, such as who they choose to fall in love with, or police people’s decisions about their own bodies, such as restricting women’s reproductive rights. As a campaigner for sexual health and reproductive rights, I know that access to safe abortion and quality contraception empowers women and girls and can save lives. I implore the Indonesian authorities to change course and remove all the problematical articles that belong in the last century.

name: Barbara Ann GIBSON
text: – Mr President, I continue to be both amazed and appalled that, in 2019, we still have laws that discriminate and try to regulate basic human rights like having sex outside of marriage or keeping people who love each other from being married. This Criminal Code violates everything I believe in. It should be stopped, and I am proud that we are standing up in solidarity for the LGBT community, women and others in Indonesia who would be affected by it.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I, too, would like to join my colleagues in condemning the parties to this new draft criminal code. We firmly believe that the Indonesian Government is our stable partner, we want to have good relations with them, good cooperation. Indonesia is indeed a strategic country in the region. On the other hand, if such a draconian and vague draft criminal code is being tabled, I think it is our duty to really speak to our partner.  I believe in the universality of fundamental human rights. I do not believe that we must spread all human rights everywhere as we perceive them in the European context, but fundamental human rights, such as the right to life, the right to a lawful judge, the right to punishment only on the basis of the law and the fundamental aspects of a fair trial, these are things that I think are truly universal. I therefore firmly believe that both the current Commission and, of course, the new entrant will be vigorous on this matter and we will actively negotiate with the GOI to ensure that this draft criminal code also aduches these amendments.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, Indonesia, a stable democracy with free and fair elections, diverse and active media and a vibrant civil society, has made important progress over the last years in establishing a legal framework for protecting human rights and improving democratic freedoms. The long modernisation process of the decades-old Criminal Code has brought to the fore positive developments, for example restricting the scope and use of the death penalty. Yet this process has raised concerns on a number of human rights—related issues, drawing criticism domestically and the attention of the international community. The European Union has monitored closely over the years the revision of the Criminal Code through regular engagement with Government, Parliament, civil society and international partners. Some of the most controversial amendments relate inter alia to the provisions of blasphemy, decriminalisation of extramarital sex and married cohabitation and provisions with the potential to limit freedom of expression and the rights of women, LGBTI and religious minorities. We call upon Indonesia, currently a non-permanent member of the United Nations Security Council, to uphold its national and international obligations and to respect human rights and fundamental freedoms and act accordingly. The European Union has made multiple outreach efforts towards the Indonesian authorities. For example, in 2018, the EU Delegation and EU Member States met with the Minister for Justice and Human Rights and, in the summer of this year, they met with the relevant Parliament’s Commission. A noticeable development has been the removal of the draft provision outlawing same-sex relations. Indonesia’s President, Joko Widodo, announced at the end of September the postponement of the vote on the revision of the Criminal Code, referring the debate to the new Parliament, in place since October this year. At the forthcoming annual EU—Indonesia Human Rights Dialogue, to be held in Brussels on 8 November, the European Union will continue to engage on the revision of the Criminal Code and will recall Indonesia’s obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debate. (The sitting was suspended at 11.50 a.m.)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, Parliament has decided to award ilham Tohti the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought.  Ilham Tohti is a professor of economics and a defender of the rights of the Uyghur minority in China. He has worked hard to improve understanding between Uyghurs and Han in China and has been imprisoned for life.  The European Parliament, in addition to expressing its full support for its work, calls for his immediate release by the Chinese authorities.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, yesterday, during the debate on Turkish military operations in north-east Syria, a Member of this Parliament acted in an unacceptable manner, showing an aggressive and disrespectful attitude towards his colleagues and this institution.  I would also like to stress, supported by the chairmen of the political groups, that I will no longer tolerate any behaviour that would damage the dignity and reputation of this Parliament. Under Rule 176(1) of Parliament's Rules of Procedure, I have decided to impose a penalty for serious violation of Rule 10(3) on Angelo Ciocca, who during yesterday's sitting adopted a turbulent course of action which included abandoning his seat and throwing an object to the ground in the centre of the Chamber. The sanction consists of the loss of the right to the daily allowance for a period of ten days and a temporary suspension from participation in all parliament's activities for a period of five days in which Parliament and its bodies, committees and delegations meet, as of 4 November 2019, without prejudice, of course, to its right to vote in plenary and subject to strict compliance with Members' rules of conduct.  The decision has been notified to the Member concerned who has the right to appeal internally against this decision to the Bureau pursuant to Rule 177. Ladies and gentlemen, at this time of the beginning of parliamentary activity, there have been certain behaviours which are to be taken up both in language and in behaviour. That is why I have written other letters to Members and I will wait for their answers. We have a great spirit of tolerance and freedom in this Parliament, but language and behaviour must be adapted to respect for this institution. * ***

name: Javier MORENO SÁNCHEZ
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today I want to share with you and I do so with great emotion, a historic event that is currently unfolding in Spain, my country, with the transfer, with all the legal guarantees, of the mortal remains of dictator Franco. He's being moved from a public mausoleum to a common cemetery.  Please, a little dignity right now. With the exhumation of the mortal remains of dictator Franco the Government of Pedro Sánchez is fulfilling its commitment and returning historical and democratic dignity to Spain and the Spaniards. Once again it is shown that Spain is a great democracy, modern, open and that it wants to close a page of its history, a very tragic page.  I believe that today all Democrats must pay tribute to the victims of the Civil War, to the victims of Francoism, to their descendants, to their relatives, to my grandparents, to my mother and to my father. And a son of migrants asks you to do so. He's won democracy. And this is the house of democracy.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, under Article 59 paragraph 4, paragraph 4, of the regulation, I ask, as chairman of the relevant committee, that this matter be referred to the REGI Committee for inter-institutional negotiations.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: – Mr President, it is a matter of order.  When voting on paragraph 18, part two — 18/2 — of the list of votes on Thomas Cook Group, the People's Group has an error and the vote has to be positive.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: President of the LIBE Commission. – Mr President, just one minute to say that it is a journey in which we once again mourn the tragic death of thirty-nine human beings, victims of the networks and mafias dealing with people.  We mourn the deaths in road traffic, mourn the deaths in the Sahara, and mourn the deaths at sea. But we also regret that, by two votes, it has not been possible to express a message of solidarity, not only with those who lose their lives at sea, but with the Member States of the European Union, so that there is a European mechanism for saving lives at sea. I'm terribly sorry, Mr. President.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, I have only a short oral amendment: ‘stress in particular the role of the responsibility of the French President, Emmanuel Macron, on the rejection of the opening of the negotiations on enlargement and its damaging impact on the credibility of the European Union’. (Applause)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: That concludes voting time. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments pending explanations of vote)

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, the collapse of the Thomas Cook Group has had a serious effect on consumers, employees and businesses across Europe. Across South-East England, an estimated 21 000 customers are waiting for refunds for their trips, protected by ATOL and EU legislation. Gatwick, the largest charter airport in the UK, is the biggest employer in and around Crawley. More than 500 jobs at the airport were dependent on Thomas Cook. I’m pleased to see the Parliament calling for a thorough analysis of the collapse, better to anticipate – and hopefully to prevent – these situations happening in future. The resolution also highlights the possibilities provided by the Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) to assist people who have lost their jobs. The UK Government should make use of this facility to offer training and assistance to those seeking new jobs. I’m writing to the Secretary of State to urge her to do so at the earliest opportunity.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Madam President, when I step off the train this evening in Leicester, I will immediately see the statue of Thomas Cook, there to commemorate Thomas Cook, his business, and indeed some of the first pioneering journeys he organised. In fact, in 1885, his first trip organised to Europe took in Brussels and Strasbourg, the cities, of course, of our European Parliament. And of course, the passengers on those first journeys organised by Thomas Cook into Europe will not have had the protection of ATOL or, indeed, the European Union. We must make sure that passengers affected by the collapse of travel companies today, and indeed the workers of such companies, are fully protected in the future and that the lessons are learnt from the devastating collapse of Thomas Cook, which has affected 600 000 passengers and many thousands of workers across the UK and Europe.

name: François-Xavier BELLAMY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, are we serious parliamentarians? We voted this morning on a resolution on the bankruptcy of Thomas Cook and another on Turkey's behaviour, which directly concern the action of the European Union. I would like to take a step back and I take the floor here to express my astonishment at many of the resolutions on which our debates or votes are based.  Have we solved all our problems so well that we can now deal with the problems of others? Is the European Union going so well that we, as European parliamentarians, can devote so much time to teaching the rest of the world? And by doing so, by the way, are we so sure that we do not roll back the causes we claim to be defending? For by giving us a right of perpetual interference in the internal affairs of sovereign countries, we often contribute to further increasing tensions, and this is even more serious when it comes to Member States of the European Union. Let us doubt democracy in some countries, for example Poland, to claim to settle debates concerning their internal affairs in their place.  Parliamentary work is to say the law on behalf of those who elected us and for them. It is about acting on the real to serve good and justice in our countries. Everything happens today as if, unable to act on our destiny, we spend our time commenting on that of others, as if we were becoming talkative as we became powerless. I feel like I have sometimes joined a fictitious tribunal, rather than a real parliament.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I agree that we must help in such a huge effect of the collapse of this travel agency, that we are to help customers, of course consumers. The cross-border effect in this case is indisputable, the chain has, of course, affected customers, consumers, entrepreneurs. On the other hand, I would like to stress that the member states have the primary responsibility and that is their right. I did not like the way colleagues on the left side of the spectrum tried to draw the Commission into the solution of this issue. There have also been proposals to reduce the huge remuneration that managers have been getting, that is simply a matter for shareholders, I think, or customers in particular, it is a matter of private law and I do not think it is appropriate for public power to step in. So, on my part, this is a kind of condemnation of the egalitarian approach that was in the motion for a resolution, yet I supported it because a substantial part of the proposal did not pass.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Madam President, when Greens in this House pushed for public reporting of bank profits back in 2015, the banks screamed that this would bankrupt them – but they’re still thriving. Having public information about how companies are shifting their profits is the only way we can ensure that they pay a fair share of tax. No wonder many of them are resisting. But European governments should not shelter these tax avoiders. The Council’s Working Group on Company Law will meet tomorrow to discuss public country—by—country reporting for all companies. It seems that the German position is shifting and I welcome this, although I’m ashamed to add that the UK will play no part in this vital policy change. Member States must break the deadlock in Council to ensure transparent reporting by corporations. If European cooperation means anything, it must mean cooperating in the interests of citizens who need properly-funded public services and small businesses who cannot compete with corporations who cheat on their taxes.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, as rapporteur on this point, I am very glad that Parliament has confirmed the political view that tax transparency is extremely important in the fight against tax evasion. It has been said here both during the debate and now that the key issue is the position of the Council, where some states are blocking us from adopting this proposal. The Finnish Presidency declared here in the debate that it would try to move the Council's position. I keep my fingers crossed that, because then the whole material could be approved, because Parliament's position is consistent in this respect, both in this and in the last period.  So now it is up to the Council, then the legal basis needs to be discussed, but that is more of a technical matter and then there is nothing to prevent us from re tinging this issue of tax transparency in this way.

name: Virginie JORON
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Turkey's aggression in northern Syria implies a flagrant violation of international and humanitarian law and a violation of Syrian sovereignty. It is incomprehensible that Turkey was not immediately called upon to stop attacking the Kurds, our allies in the fight against Daesh. We are now risking the return of Daesh and new waves of migration, which Turkey threatens us with. This clearly shows how important it is to protect our internal and external borders.  The European Union was able to hit Russia with sanctions during the Ukraine crisis. So how can we explain that Turkey can consider invading northern Syria without a response from us? We must act now, including by stopping all payments to this country. All funding for Turkey related to the pre-accession process and the European Union-Turkey action plan on migration should be suspended. Finally, it is crucial to launch a multilaterally organized peace process that includes the Syrian government. This is the only way forward and resolve this crisis.

name: Annika BRUNA
text: Madam President, on 9 October the Turkish army invaded north-eastern Syria. This deadly offensive hit Kurdish forces that fought Daesh. Abuses have been committed against civilians and the chaos generated by Turkey has allowed the escape of many jihadist detainees. This action has been condemned by the Member States and their citizens. Europe could have put in place strong economic sanctions against Turkey, but it did not.  After this aggression, and at a time when Ankara is blackmailing Europe, Brussels could have put a definitive end to Turkey's accession process, which is otherwise not European in terms of value, culture or geography, but it has not done so. The minimum was for Europe to stop paying billions of euros to Turkey. Our amendment calling for this judgment was rejected by 545 MEPs, ranging from the right to the Socialists to the elected representatives of En Marche. These MEPs make Europe an accomplice of Turkey.

name: Manuel BOMPARD
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the resolution on Turkey's military operations in north-eastern Syria is moving in the right direction because it condemns Turkish aggression, because it calls for its cessation and the withdrawal of all Turkish troops from Rojava. It also goes in the right direction because it reminds us that Syria's sovereignty and territorial integrity must be respected, as must the rights of all ethnic and religious components of the country.  For these reasons, I support this resolution, although I think it should have gone further. It should have condemned more strongly the murder of Havrin Khalaf and, above all, on this United Nations day, it should have called for the deployment of an international force of peacekeepers and the establishment of a no-fly zone in order to protect the Kurds and guarantee their right to internal self-determination within the framework of the Syrian state. The Kurds are our allies, let's not forget them!

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I supported this resolution, I clearly see it as an illegal, reprehensible attack by Turkey on the Kurdish minority in Syria. Unfortunately, this makes it clear that Turkey is in no way approaching European standards, but is, on the contrary, increasingly moving away. After all, we have debated this many times here in the House in the last parliamentary term, and therefore any idea that Turkey could ever be a member of the European Union is, I think, completely meaningless today.  In the long term, we will probably debate, though not here, whether Turkey should be a member of NATO at all, and whether it is still our ally at all, or whether its international policy is completely at a different from that of the countries of Euro-Atlantic civilization.

name: Martin HORWOOD
text: – Madam President, I have voted for the strongest possible condemnation of Turkish President Erdoğan’s invasion of Northern Syria, and seeing Erdoğan and Putin stitching up this shameful deal on Northern Syria with the meek compliance of Donald Trump represents a tragic day for the people of Syria and especially for those in the Kurdistan region. Responsibility for this turn of events seems to me to lie in large part with President Trump for his grotesque betrayal of his Kurdish allies. I’m delighted the European Union is taking a strong stand on this. In a dangerous world, when human rights and the rights of minorities seem constantly at risk and when our allies like the USA are currently proving so unreliable, it has never been more clear that all the 28 countries of the European Union, including the United Kingdom, should speak together with one strong voice on foreign policy whenever we can.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, of course, the Turkish invasion of northern Syria deserves condemnation, and it is good that such a statement has passed here. On the other hand, there's something missing. Let's not pretend the situation is completely black and white. Firstly, as the European Union, we should not give the impression that we are perhaps supporting forces that are moving towards the territorial disintegration of another state, which I think would be unacceptable interference with the internal order of that state. In this case, Turkey. Secondly, let us also say that if the European Union really wants to live up to its reputation as a global player, it must seize on something other than mere resolutions and accusing the United States of not fulfilling its obligations.  I read President Trump's statement yesterday, which I think many people here in this courtroom might even like. He said that it is not the task of American military power or military power to play the world's gendarme, but that other countries must also live up to their responsibilities. And that is, of course, true, and I fear that neither the European Union nor its Member States have received their responsibilities on this matter and are not getting their responsibilities, and in any case no resolution, however powerful, will solve this.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I did not support this motion for a resolution, I also did not support a number of amendments, and I welcome the fact that, in the end, this resolution – by two votes, that is, close, but – did not pass. I believe that it is not possible to promote the refugee business. I can't call it anything else. I understand that many nonprofits have good intentions. We must prevent the victims of human lives, but above all we must ensure that people do not have to flee their homes. So that, in an emergency, they have good conditions in refugee camps as close as possible to their country so that they can return.  And if there are refugees who are entitled to international protection, they should be able to obtain it legally. I believe that this effort to create new redistribution mechanisms for refugees is not a working solution. On the one hand, it is really rejected by some Member States, but above all it is to support the refugee business. So thank you and I am glad that this resolution has not passed.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Madam President, I think this resolution today being defeated by just two votes is a bleak day for this Parliament. Is this issue complicated and complex? Yes, it can be. Should we deal with and bring to justice people traffickers? Yes, we should. But this issue actually is also really straightforward in my mind as well, because what it boils down to is about whether we support the idea of rescuing kids drowning in the sea, families, parents, children, making the most perilous of journeys, in real desperation, fleeing persecution and war. So I want my constituents to know, and be under no doubt whatsoever, that I voted today in favour of proper search and rescue in the Mediterranean, in favour of bringing traffickers to justice and making sure those who seek to help are not criminalised, and that I voted today for measures that ultimately come down to a basic sense of humanity and decency.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! It is with great satisfaction that I have noted that my voice has so appreciablely, so tangiblely, that this motion for a resolution drafted by Mr Aguilar will collapse. I am fully aware that, on the one hand, such an emotional kind of word – which is blackmail, precisely moral, emotional – on the left side of the chamber, means that public opinion in the European Union may feel that something bad has happened. No, ladies and gentlemen. We have put down a resolution that has de facto encouraged hundreds of millions of people to go to the coast of Tunisia, Libya, Morocco and try to get to Europe in search of a better life. This is driving business for smuggling groups. NGOs are de facto competing with criminal groups today. As Minister of the Interior and Administration of the Government of the Republic of Poland, I have repeatedly encountered published data which show that today criminal groups benefit much more from people smuggling than from arms or drug trafficking. It is very good that this resolution has collapsed.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, I voted against this resolution, I am glad that it did not pass, and let us be clear that it was simply a dead end. We cannot fight effectively the smuggling of people, those who take advantage of human misfortune, and at the same time adopt similar resolutions that will not only stop them, but will also instee them to do so. We cannot stand up for NGOs such as Captain Carola Racket, who has broken several laws in her rescue of refugees from the Mediterranean, disreased maritime law and will have to face the consequences. We must focus on prevention, we must focus on how to help those countries from which refugees are flowing, in order to stabilise the political and economic situation in these countries and to stop the influx of refugees, and we must not adopt resolutions that, on the contrary, will indust people smugglers to continue their activities.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I would like to explain why I supported the European Parliament resolution criticising the actions of the Governments of France, Denmark and the Netherlands. These countries have blocked the opening of accession negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania. I consider this a major strategic mistake. Of course, these negotiations would be long, complicated, perhaps with an uncertain end, but they must one day be initiated in order to simply give these countries the motivation and perspective that these countries, and especially their citizens, urgently need for the reforms that they need to implement.  North Macedonia recently reached a historic agreement with Greece on the name of the country, an important achievement that we could also appreciate with this act. In this context, I would like to point out that the European Union should not lose any further influence over the Western Balkans; tomorrow Serbia will sign an act of accession to the Euro-Asian Union. I don't think that's a good trend.

name: Irena JOVEVA
text: – Madam President, why did I vote in favour of the resolution on blocking accession negotiations? Because, in particular, one Member State is the credibility of the entire Union.  I can't take the French position. Not because my country slovenia and then Macedonia were once part of a common country. And not because my mother was Macedonian, but because I'm disappointed as an individual, as an ordinary man who knows what it's like to have a promise for years, and who does everything that was asked of him to end up getting nothing.  The opening of accession negotiations would only be a sign that Albania and North Macedonia are on the right track, although both know very well that, of course, they still have a long way to go. We all know that. Of course, reforms are needed in the Union, and we all know that, but, would the beginning, I would like to emphasise, the start, of accession negotiations, be a threat to reforms or to the Union as such? I'm begging you.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab When, during yesterday's debate, to which the Speaker of the Parliament of North Macedonia listened, there were quite arrogant, rather unwise voices, giving such a testimony that it was the representatives of large states who could, ironically, address representatives of small nations, small societies, in this case the Slavic state, which is North Macedonia, i.e. the words reminded me of the words (historians dispute as to whether talleyrand or Napoleon Bonaparte were the authors of these words) , but I dedicate it to the President of France: "It's worse than a crime - it's a mistake." If France has blocked the accession of this small, proud, brave Slavic nation such as North Macedonia, I will recall here the words of another historical figure, Winston Churchill: "The Balkans are the soft underbelly of Europe." France, the Netherlands and Denmark today leave the Balkans as the soft underbelly of Europe in the case of Albania, perhaps in the hands of The Wahabic radicals of Saudi Arabia and, in the case of North Macedonia, in the hands of Russia. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, I, of course, voted in favour of this resolution because I come from that part of Europe that was only adopted into the European Union 15 years ago. That is why our countries have no moral right to prevent anyone from accessing the European Union if they so wish. We have always supported the further enlargement of the European Union. On the other hand, I must say that we should express some understanding of the kind of enlargement fatigue in some of our neighbours or some of the so-called old Member States. We often complain that we are not well understood or that our Central European, Eastern European experience is not well reflected in the West. Unfortunately, this is true, I am reminded here, for example, of the witch-hunt that is happening against Hungary or Poland. So when we ourselves ask for a better understanding, we should also try to show it to our neighbours. Maybe if we start to understand each other better, we can eliminate a lot of mutual misunderstandings.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the appointment of EBA Executive Director Farkas as AFME Chief Executive, by Paul Tang and Jonás Fernández, on behalf of the S&D Group, and Sven Giegold (O-000031/2019 - B9-0054/2019) (2019/2888(RSP)). Before I open the debate, I would like to inform you that, in order to request catch-the-eye and blue cards, it will be possible to use both the standard registration and the new system allowing Members to register electronically. Therefore, I invite you to always bring your voting cards. Should you wish to register for catch-the-eye, I invite you to do so starting from now, without waiting for the end of the debate.

name: Paul TANG
text: author. – Madam President, thank you also for explaining the catch-the-eye procedure. I appreciate it. Recently, it was announced that Mr Adam Farkas, Executive Director of the European Banking Authority (EBA), will become the CEO of the Association for Financial Markets in Europe (AFME). It’s remarkable, right? It’s astonishing. It’s flabbergasting that the supervisor of that sector becomes the main lobbyist for that same sector.  The EBA is responsible for supervising the EU’s banking sector and for setting technical standards implementing key financial regulations. This makes the EBA of fundamental importance in supervising the financial sector. It also makes it a constant lobbying target for the industry. Especially AFME, with its technical expertise and focus on implementing measures drafted by the EBA, has permanent interaction with the European Banking Authority. You can just imagine my surprise when I learned that the EBA’s Executive Director will become AFME’s CEO.  Farkas’ move gives the banking lobby privileged insight into the EBA’s decision—making and private access to high—level staff. As such, banks will be able to excessively influence key pieces of legislation. What is worse, this move may give EU staff the wrong idea that if you are friendly towards the sector that you are meant to regulate then you will be awarded a well—paying job. In other words, this opens the door for very perverse incentives.  The EU rules need to prevent this and want to prevent this. Article 16 of the EU Staff Regulations states that EU officials are prohibited from lobbying staff of their former institutions for a period of one year. As CEO of AFME, maintaining contact with the EBA is the headline of one’s job description. Is it realistic to expect Farkas to sit in AFME’s tower, avoiding contact with his organisation’s main interlocutor?  The Staff Regulations also allow the blocking of professional moves if that leads to a conflict with the legitimate interests of the institution. Is good supervision of the banking sector no longer a legitimate interest of the European Banking Authority? Because that’s what’s severely undermined by Farkas’ move. Furthermore, if this case of revolving doors doesn’t lead to a conflict of interest sufficiently severe to block it, if Farkas is allowed to join AFME, any EU official will be allowed to join any organisation. In effect, it renders Article 16 meaningless.  Yesterday, we launched a petition with 58 NGOs against this case of revolving doors. Many people are disappointed, frustrated, or even outright angry. On behalf of the citizens of Europe, I therefore ask you: do you deem Farkas’ move to be in line with the Europeans institutions high ethical standards? Do you agree with Mr Farkas remaining in his position until the end of January? Will you exert pressure on the EBA to change its position and block Mr Farkas’ professional move? And what will you do to put our ethical standards into practice and prevent further cases of revolving doors from undermining citizens’ trust in our institutions?

name: Paul TANG
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the European Banking Authority (EBA) is bound by the Staff Regulations, which contain a comprehensive ethical framework for officials of European institutions and agencies. This framework includes post-employment restrictions, which were strengthened by the 2014 Staff Regulations reform. The EBA Board of Supervisors is the decision-making body responsible for deciding on and enforcing post-employment restrictions. It decided on the requirements to be imposed on Mr Farkas for him to join the Association for Financial Markets in Europe (AFME).  The European Commission representative does not vote in the Board of Supervisors. However, the Commission is a Board member and is thereby entitled to contribute to discussions at Board level. In this context, the Commission pleaded for the strictest possible approach towards Mr Farkas’ departure, taking into consideration the Staff Regulations.  The decision taken by the EBA Board of Supervisors includes restrictions on Mr Farkas both while in service at the EBA and after leaving the EBA. With regard to restrictions while in service at the EBA, the decision taken by the EBA Board of Supervisors includes measures to cover the notice period to which he is entitled under the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants. These measures include immediate cessation of any activities related to the preparation of EBA regulatory or supervisory policies, attendance at Board meetings, external representation of EBA and access to information outside the operations and accounting department. The restrictions also include three months’ ‘gardening leave’ in which he ceases to exercise his role as appointing authority under the Staff Regulations and authorising officer under the Financial Regulation. He may not be on the EBA premises except upon the request of the Chairperson and he ceases to have access to EBA systems.  With regard to restrictions after leaving the service, the EBA Board of Supervisors has ruled that Mr Farkas may not engage in lobbying or advocacy vis-à-vis the EBA nor have professional contact with EBA staff for a period of 24 months. He may not contribute to the work of the Association for Financial Markets in Europe on any topics treated by him in his last three years of service at the EBA for a period of 18 months.  Therefore, restrictions are in place to prevent conflicts of interest during the notice period until the effective departure of Mr Farkas, as well as after his leaving the EBA. It is the responsibility of the EBA to enforce these restrictions.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, the last few years have been hard years to believe and trust the institutions. According to all surveys, we perceive that European citizens have less confidence in democratic institutions and that this lower confidence is being used by populismos and nationalisms to undermine not only the European project, but also the fundamental principles of liberal democracy.  And I must say that the news of the departure of the Executive Director of the European Banking Authority to one of the main European financial lobbies contributes to this perception of the lack of independence of the public institutions, to that perception that public servants, officials and politicians, in the minds of some, do not serve the true purposes that have brought us here.  And I believe that this occasion is a good opportunity to reflect on the system we have of control. For the Commission to defend a system in which the incumbents — the people who are working with those colleagues who are going to leave that institution to work elsewhere — are the most appropriate to assess whether or not there is a conflict of interest, it doesn't really make any sense.  I'm not going to discuss the application of regulation. What I do want to discuss is that this regulation makes no sense and that we need to have an independent institution, an independent European institution that assesses, on a case-by-case basis, these kinds of situations, because it will be impossible for people working with those who wish to leave the public institutions towards lobbies to be able to have an independent criterion.  And, therefore, I think this debate is important to open up that debate on how we review the rules.

name: Damien CARÊME
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, as my colleague has just said, collusion between private and public interests can no longer last. The mix of genders and slippers rightly undermines the confidence of citizens in the European institutions. In France, it is a national sport. Mr. Macron worked at Rothschild Bank before becoming minister, then president, the prime minister was a lobbyist for the nuclear group Areva, but we are told that all this is normal and that it has nothing to do with gifts made to the wealthy, nor with the strange craze for the financial abyss that represents nuclear today. Europe is not left behind in terms of slippers with a former President of the European Commission, Barroso, who was debauched by the goldman Sachs bank.  Today, we are faced with another case of bewildering slippers where a senior official, currently in charge of supervising banks and limiting the risks of a new financial crisis, will become, in a few weeks, the director of the main financial lobby, whose essential role , if needed to be recalled - is to curb all new banking regulations as much as possible. From February 2020, he is the Executive Director of the European Banking Authority, 'Dum Farkas', who will become the Director General of the Association for Financial Markets in Europe (AFME), one of the leading financial sector lobbying groups. Some conditions have been put in place - and you have recalled them earlier - by the European Banking Authority, such as a 24-month ban on lobbying staff of its former institution or, even more unlikely, a 18-month ban on advising or working on matters directly related to its previous work. But who really believes in it? And most importantly, who can verify it? And even if he does not lobby, he is in possession of valuable and confidential documents and information that he will now be able to use in the name of private interests.  This situation is scandalous and should not be allowed. That's why the rules on slippers need to change. They must be stricter to preserve the integrity of our institutions and strengthen the confidence of citizens. They should leave no room for suspicions of conflict and collusion of interest. For example, there is a need to set much longer transition periods between two activities and potential conflicts of interest.  I would add that these rules must be common to all eu-government institutions and agencies to avoid conditions set on a case-by-case basis and according to the agency concerned. Finally, we need to create an independent European ethics authority. This authority would be responsible for overseeing the proper application of these common rules.  But in the meantime, ladies and gentlemen, we can already act at the level of our institution to preserve its integrity in the face of these scandalous practices. That is why I propose to you, as Parliament has already done for Monsanto's lobbyists, to refuse to grant Mr Farkas the right of access to the European Parliament. That would be a strong signal to affirm our commitment to combating conflicts of interest. The time for small arrangements and exchanges of good processes between big bosses and senior officials must now end.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: – Madam President, I really welcome the fact that we can have this debate in the House today, although it is certainly not the best time or the best day; many of our colleagues have already left after the votes, but well...  On the other hand, I welcome the presence of citizens in the rostrum, who can follow this debate, and I take this opportunity to greet them because it is a very important debate, as highlighted by my group colleagues, Mr Tang and Mr Fernández, who I congratulate on having raised this oral question, and my colleague and also friend Caréme ( of the Greens) , because we are clearly facing at least one appearance of conflict of interest. And we already know, Mr. Mimica, that Caesar's wife should not only be honest, but must also seem so.  So it is hardly understandable that, in this case, such favourable conditions have been applied to Mr Farkas, because, as has been said before, it is hard to believe that, by saying that he is prohibited from giving advice on one thing or another related to his previous activity, the problem is solved, because, as has been said — and colleagues who have raised it are absolutely right— , is practically unverifiable. That is, any of us sit at a table and start giving information about its previous stage, without any possibility of acting against it.  I welcome the fact that the Commission, with its voice — and I do not vote — on that Board — in that Council, I mean — of the European Banking Authority, has called for the strictest application of the rule, but it is clear that it has not been sufficient.  The rules must be made stricter and also their application. It is clear that in this case a mandatory transition of at least twelve months should have been applied to Mr Farkas.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Madam President, I wish to thank the Commission for the answers, but I’m afraid – you heard my colleagues – they are not convincing or adequate. You mentioned the conditions placed upon Mr Farkas’ move. I’ve read them and, to be frank, they are simply inadequate. I already mentioned the impossibility of banning Mr Farkas from having professional contacts with the EBA. Will he really not interact with his organisation’s main interlocutor? Besides, is not the private context just as much of a problem as the professional context?  Indeed, the EBA also states that Mr Farkas can’t contribute to activities on topics directly linked to the work that he carried out in the last three years. Frankly, I find this laughable. I cannot think of a single topic that AFME covers that doesn’t fall within the remit of the EBA and doesn’t relate to the work of Mr Farkas. I ask again, will Mr Farkas sit in the AFME tower, working on nothing substantial? Will he simply be AFME’s poster-boy, and who will monitor whether afterwards Farkas abides by the EBA’s restrictions as also put forward by Jonás Fernández? Who makes sure that the restrictions are monitored? It’s even worse that Mr Farkas is allowed to stay at the EBA right up to his departure. His interests diverge from the EBA, his loyalty is fundamentally compromised, and still the EBA makes the European taxpayer feed the bill for Farkas’ luxurious transition period. It’s unacceptable.  Finally, and this was raised here as well, I missed from your response, Mr Commissioner, a sense of the structural pattern of revolving doors with the EU’s institutions. After Barroso’s move to Goldman Sachs, Neelie Kroes to Uber and Jonathan Hill to UBS you still fail to take appropriate action. When will you finally enforce your own rules and live up to your and our standards? When will you finally put an end to the Achilles heel of your institution’s integrity?

name: Patrick BREYER
text: – Madam President, when a senior bank supervisor, while still in office, negotiates working for the other side, there is clearly a public appearance that this person is being bought out of office. Public trust in the financial sector is low anyway, and they have the impression that it is intertwined with banking supervision. Therefore, a cooling-off period of just a few weeks is clearly insufficient. Also, we have no idea when he started the negotiations. Was that at a time when he was still exercising his functions and did it have any influence on his functions? Can someone tell us about that? I believe that there is a very legitimate interest to have a sufficient cooling—off period to avoid even the appearance of a conflict of interest. It’s an issue of trust. But if one thinks the Staff Regulations are not sufficient for imposing such a period then would one not propose a reform?

name: Patrick BREYER
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for this important debate under this oral question. The Commission considers that its high ethical standards would be best enforced in the European Banking Authority (EBA) and more generally across all the agencies by putting in place a harmonised legal framework. This Commission, and I might also speak on behalf of the incoming European Commission, will also be taking into account the debate and the outcome of this debate here in Parliament when looking at and reviewing the post-employment ethical regulations.  Under the existing legal framework, it is the responsibility of the EBA Board of Supervisors to implement this legal framework by independently taking decisions on post-employment restrictions in accordance with its founding regulations. It is also the responsibility of the EBA Board of Supervisors and of the EBA to check and enforce these restrictions.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The debate is closed.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: I declare adjourned the session of the European Parliament.
